1549$Condition: Disorder characterized by Stiff, Tender & Painful Muscles$8/26/2011 11:49:31 AM$Reviewer: gne661, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$I suffered with severe  Fibromyalgia for 18 mo. before diagnosis. Moved around like an 80 yr old! Foot pain was the worst but I had it pretty much all over all muscles and joints. Even though I did yoga and tryed other meds for the pain they made me too dopey. After Diagnosis, 1st Savella helped alot, but seemed to be working less and less after 3rd week titration.  Insurance wouldnt cover it, so I started cymbalta instead.  It only took a week to get through the hot spells and a little dizzyness, started 1 30mg aday now on 2 aday.That is the right dose for Fibromyalgia, No More than that! It started working right away.  I am about 70% better most days, and if you were as bad as I was, you would not be worried about possible withdrawal from a new med, or some side effects!  Anything that helps me get my life back closer to what I had before is worth a try!  I was in chronic pain for 18mo. no end in sight, getting very depressed, disabled from the chronic pain and stiffness, neck and headaches.  Now I am enjoying life again, not 100%, but thank God there is something for people to try for Fibro.now! This med might help you too like it did me. Remember that some people are on too many Rx's at the same time and then add another. It's not an accurate review unless they disclose all Rx's they are on and how much. Or they could be mis-diagnosed.  when you read the scary reviews remember that.  I'm glad I didn't let it scare me.  Good luck!

1552$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/26/2011 8:42:13 AM$Reviewer: Kdub, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$4$I have been on Cymbalta for over 5 years. I take 120 mgs a day and it helps keep me level minded. I also take anti-anxiety medication so I am tired alot. 
1553$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/26/2011 12:36:07 AM$Reviewer: lelacey, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$1$1$I have been on cymbalta for just about 5years now. The first year was great and all my depression symptoms went away. However I have noticed a few negative side affects...prior to taking cymbalta I never had anxiety now I get it quite often and have had many anxiety/panic attacks. My over all health has gone down in last few years...about 30 pounds of weight gain, high blood pressure, and severe migrane attacks (never had those prior either), and more recently hypothyroidism. Not positive these things are related to the cymbalta use but deffintly the aniexty and migranes. The absolute worst part of cymbalta is attempting to wean off of it. I have made a few attempts, this last time I gradually wean down over a period of 4 months. I got all the way down to only 20mg every other day, but the withdrawls were unbearable! Yes, physically painful in muscle's and joint's as well as terrible migranes and vertigo, mood swings, and anxiety. I feel like I'm a prisoner to cymbalta, I hate it...and regret the day I agreed with my doctor to begin use. Before beginning cymbalta do research on the side effects and withdrawl symptoms of going off...I wish I did! My doctor now tells me it is one of the hardest anti-depressants to quit.

I am concerned about this complicating my health.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$3$4$"I started Cymbalta 30mg/day for 7 days and 60mg/day thereafter. I have been on it for about 17 days now and I feel better mentally (meaning I seem to ""care"" more about things: showering
column3: cleaning
column4: exercising
column5: etc) but I have been feeling poor physically. Since I started the Cymbalta I have been experiencing moderate to severe stomach upset - including gas pains
column6: loose stools
column7: frequent movements
column8: painful movements
column9: etc. I also have been experiencing nausea and dizziness. For example
column10: I will be driving down the road and all of a sudden a wave of dizziness will overcome me where I feel the road is slanting or I feel like I am going to pass out behind the wheel. It is very scary and quite unnerving. I also have been experiencing ""shots"" of pain in odd places throughout my body. My wrist
column11: or calf
column12: or most recently behind my left eye. These ""shots"" of pain only last 30 to 40 seconds but are severe enough to make me wince and cringe until they are over. I also have been finding it more difficult to sleep at night
column13: and nearly impossible to stay asleep during the night. I might ask my psychiatrist for a sleep aide to remedy this situation
column14: as nearly all OTC sleep medicines I have used do not help for long periods of time. I also don't like capsule beads. A few positives: I feel my sex drive is back 110% - I want it all the time
column15: multiple times a day. I can not seem to get enough. This is a welcomed side effect from my boyfriend
column16: after a LONG dry spell under Lexapro. I am also finding my appetite to be smaller
column17: sometimes I have to force myself to eat (though that is very rare). I also find myself having much less lower back aches and pains. I am concerned about all I am reading regarding negative side effects and withdrawals. I will have to discuss this further with my psychiatrist. I also feel I may need an anti anxiety medication to get me through those times when a single anti-depressant doesn't cut it. I hope to report back when I have been on this dosage a little longer."

column6: in fact I've gotten addicted to muesli of all things. Takes longer to reach orgasm
column7: especially compared to being on Wellbutrin
column8: but when it does hit-- OH my GOD ;) I would have to have six in a row of those little firecracker Wellbutrin orgasms to reach the same intensity of my first one on this drug! So
column9: not a bad trade-off. Sleeping DEEPLY for the first time in years. All in all
column10: it's a good experience so far and I'm hopeful about the future."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $3$1$2$"Was prescribed this drug for depression and had a rough adjustment period. Took 30mg for a week
column3: during which time I was nauseous
column4: dizzy
column5: and suffered some of the worst headaches of my life.  Increased to 60mg after that
column6: and began to feel better mentally.  I actually could get through a day at work without bursting into tears for no reason
column7: and I started feeling moments of happiness again.  The side effects during this time however were quite irritating.  I began to bite the inside of my mouth during sleep
column8: and sometimes when awake and not even when eating! I ended up with painful mouth ulcers from repeated biting
column9: and this lasted about a month after switching to the 60mg. I then began experiencing insomnia at night
column10: and bouts of nearly narcoleptic drowsiness at work
column11: along with shortness of breath and vertigo.  Then I got on the scale and realized with horror that I had gained 20 pounds!!! I had already gained 15 pounds in the 8 months prior to taking the medication.  I am willing to accept responsibility for THOSE pounds
column12: because I sat home and ate like a pig for weeks after the suicide of my sister.  I was NOT prepared to gain 20 pounds in 3 months while working and eating healthfully.  The shock of being a 5'4"" female who now weighs close to 175 pounds was enough to send me into a three week drinking binge. So much for the few months of feeling slightly better.  I am now debating on whether or not to quit taking this medication
column13: as some reviewers have suggested that it may cause further weight gain.  I am not prepared to deal with that
column14: and I really wish they would list weight gain as a side effect on the patient info! I would NEVER have agreed to take this medication if I had known it were a possibility.  In summary
column15: the damage that this medication has caused to my self esteem and my sex life are likely irreversible and I was probably less depressed before Cymbalta than I am right now."

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$5$"My psychiatrist tried weaning me from Lexapro and implementing Cymbalta in its place simultaneously. Not only is this life-threatening (all over the Cymbalta label
column3: it says DO NOT TAKE WITH SSRI MEDICATION)
column4: he responded to my worsening condition by doubling my dose to twice the therapeutic level (120 mg/day- I refused). He'd already done the same with my Adderrall
column5: which he's been using as a supplement to SSRI/SNRI medication to treat ""resistant symptoms."" I am prescribed 60 mg/day Adderrall; the therapeutic dose is 40. Additionally
column6: he doubled my Klonipin
column7: which was initially .5 mg/AM
column8: .5 mg/noon
column9: and 1 mg/bedtime. Now I'm on a total of 4 mg/day- again 2x the therapeutic dose.

column1: About 2 mos. into Cymbalta (1 mo. at 60 mg)
column2: I began to feel that something was very wrong. I am a therapist myself
column3: so it took a LOT to call my psychiatrist's cell phone at 10PM 3 nights ago. He stated that he would follow up in the AM & probably call in a Lexapro prescription
column4: because I was probably having withdrawal symptoms (you think? I've been on it for as long as I can remember and he tried to wean me in 4 weeks!)...and he only said this AFTER I suggested it. I also re-read ALL my prescription labels & learned that NONE of my medications should be taken all at once. I take Omeprazole for GERD
column5: which is NOT supposed to be taken with Adderrall
column6: as it prevents absorption in the gut. Cymbalta is not to be taken with antacids OR SSRIs (Lexapro)
column7: or Klonopin
column8: or by people who smoke (I smoke)
column9: as nicotine depletes it in the bloodstream. Also
column10: I cannot eat; I have no appetite
column11: and have lost 20 lbs. since starting with this dr. in September...probably due to the unnecessarily high dose of Adderrall and the fact that a side effect of Cymbalta is appetite loss. I consume probably 600 calories a day
column12: all liquids. I don't even notice until nighttime. I'm a 5'10"" female & wasn't overweight to start; now I just look sick.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$1$5$"I've been taking neurontin 2400mg per day for ""fibromyalgia"" caused by syringomyelia and cervical disc damage since 2004. I have attempted Cymbalta trials twice. The first time it moderately helped both my pain and sleep...actually all I could do was sleep. I felt like I was in some kind of bizarre fog of contentment for the first month or so. Went from 30mg once a day to 30 twice a day with a goal dose of 120mg perday. Eventually however I lost the ability to sleep
column3: felt horribly hot all the time and had constipation issues. Also
column4: the med did not work well enough for me to stop the neurontin.  I had no problems reducing my dose. More recently I experienced a severe pain exacerbation and decided to give Cymbalta an other chance (after hating Savella for 2 weeks).  This time we started at 60 mg and I experienced ataxia
column5: nausea
column6: severe tremors
column7: inability to sleep
column8: and chronic over-heating.  I also would wake in the morning feeling like I'd been poked with a cattle prod and would feel an overwhelming sense of impending doom.  It continued to do this even after we backed down to 30mg. If I'd been able to sleep at night and not feel a sense of impending doom in the morning then I MIGHT say it helped my pain.  This time around I lasted only 2-3 mos on it before needing to stop taking it. I don't know why the side effects were different this time.  Oh
column9: and both times I took it my BP shot upwards and stayed higher for the duration.  I think I'll try a tricyclic next. If you must try this med
column10: have them test your liver enzymes first.  Also
column11: discuss carefully ahead of time the types of issues and side-effects that will lead you to stop taking this drug. That way your doctor will be more psychologically prepared."

column1: 1822$Condition: Neuropathic Pain$3/8/2011 1:58:21 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$3$After standing w/my firm no to this med. I finally gave in to the Dr. For months she pushed it...I heard horror stories from numerous nurses
column2: dr's and users of this med.  Insurance finally stated would cover so I figured if it helps what have I got to lose?? OMG on med for 2 days(30 mg pill)what a nightmare..I took pill at nite in case it made me tired..tired all I did was sleep I was physically exhausted just to walk up the stairs was a effort after a nap I still felt like I could sleep more which I did. When I was awake all I did was throw up. My kids thought I was seriously dying. I looked awful!! That was the first day the second was the same only I started to feel the effects more on my body. I stopped w/this med and for the next 4 days I have had body aches something awful I am not tired all the time but still not up to my energy level I was at before I now am having trouble sleeping. This is a very expensive med. and the side effects are different for all who have tried it--thanks to our body chemistry. If you are thinking about trying this med. weigh the side effects to your need for this drug.  Myself needing this for nerve damage..I should of held my ground and refused to try this. The road to where I was at 10 days ago is along hard one to get back to.Dr's should try this for afew days themselves and see what the side effects are and the recovery road to get back to normal. Then maybe they wouldn't push this drug on people. All in all this is nothing I will boast about in fact I will tell all DONT TAKE IT!!!!

column4: that after three weeks I went back to my doctor and cried because for the first time in a long time I had hope. I felt like life was fun again and I  enjoyed waking to a new day. column3: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$5$I was prescribed cymbalta for fibromyalgia; I have many medical problems gradually appearing following removal of a pituitary adenoma in 1991 and removal of approximately half of my pituitary. I take low dose of dexedrine for Sympathetic Hyperalgesia-Edema Syndrome. About a week or so after starting Cymbalta for Fibromyalgia
column4: I developed headaches in the occipital area that pain meds did not even help.  Previously my endocrinologist who performed many case studies of women with only a partial pituitary gland who also had these nagging occipital headaches.  The Dexedrine basically relieved this when even opiate pain meds did not. Another MD prescribed Cymbalta for my worsening fibromyalgia (I had terrible side effects with Savella and Lyrica previously) which started to help somewhat except I began getting these occipital headaches back.  After my last visit with my endocrinologist
column5: he told me to wean off the Cymbalta because it took away the effectiveness of the Dexedrine for the Sympathetic Hyperalgesia-Edema Syndrome.  I just finished the 3-weeek weaning off of Cymbalta and the occipital headaches are finally dissipating but my sensitity with the fibromyalgia is again increasing.

1963$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$11/11/2010 1:55:18 PM$Reviewer: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$4$first off, i started out on prozac which made me cry nonstop, and weight loss i was 120 then i dropped to 100. that pill just wasnt working, and i had taken it for a month. so i switched to cymbalta, at first it helped, i wasnt crying, i felt like doing normal activities, i was on the 50mg, so that was the first week or so, the doctor then recommended me to take one and a half, so i did, after taking 75 mg, i was sleeping constantly, i had a hard time breathing, muscle pain, and my blood pressure would rise then fall suddenly. finally the symptoms had become so bad that i thought i needed to go to the hospital because we didnt know what it could have been, but my mother told me to stop every medication i was taking, including the cymbalta so i did. today, i have woken up feeling better, small discomforts because of the endless amounts of sleep, but deff not feeling as bad as i did before. thank god for webmd because i saw all of my symptoms on there.

column1: 2010$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$10/14/2010 10:38:56 AM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$5$"I am 60 yrs old and generally fit
column2: well and healthy although I have suffered from depression for most of my adult life. I was prescribed Cynbalta approx 7/8 wks ago. It initially left me in a more calm state but I suddenly began to take most of the side effects of this drug i.e.
column3: nausea
column4: trembling
column5: panic attacks etc. I would urge anyone who is prescribed this drug to carefully look at the side effects because if you are prone to any of them
column6: then you are more than likely to develop some or most of them. My doctor actually advised me not to read the side effects which in retrospect was the wrong advice. I would advise anyone to read the side effects of any prescription drug. I am weaning myself off Cymbalta at the moment but still suffering from its effects - however
column7: I am pleased with my decision to come off it. I shall deal with my depression in my own way now
column8: probably through herbal remedies. I read one review which said ""this is the drug from hell"". I don't believe I would be so graphic but the person making the comment had been on this for several months and I truly wish her well in her recovery. One piece of advise I would offer to anyone is that if you have a decent and understanding partner then you can talk things through with their help. That's what I'm grateful for and I  will not go back on anti depressants. It's too easy for doctors to dole out this medication to an unsuspecting and trustworthy public domain. I hope my review has been a help to you."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $2$1$3$"I took Cymbalta for over a year. After that year I started having dizzy spells
column3: heart palpatations
column4: and anxiety attacks.

column1: My doctor thought that maybe these were a side affect of the Cymbalta. Instead of switching to a different antidepressant I decided to attempt to get off it.  My Doctor started me on a step down process of removing me from Cymbalta.

column2: I began to have thoughts of suicide. I was so screwed up in the head. All I wanted was for everything to just go away.

column1: I took a whole bottle of Xanax. I wanted to just go away. I wanted to leave my life. I thought that my family would be better off without me.
My son and husband found me passed out on the floor and called an ambulance. I spent two weeks in the hospital. I worked with doctors to change my drugs
column2: and I am now happy
column3: healthy
column4: and have a wonderful life.

column1: My doctor stated to me after everything was fixed ""We were poisoning you with that drug"".
I COMPLETELY agree with him. I am soo thankful to my Lord that he didn't take me home that day.
Every time I hear someone mention this drug I cringe.  Yes it helped me for a year
column2: but the process of trying to get off of it
column3: almost killed me.

column1: I encourage anyone who is talking with their doctor about taking Cymbalta
column2: to really look at things
column3: look for alternatives
column4: know FOR SURE that this is the medication for you.  Because it sure wasn't for me.

column1: 2080$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/21/2010 7:30:44 AM$Reviewer: BrettnNM
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$4$"Cymbalta
column3: The Wonder Drug

column1: Hi there.
Over the past 10 years
column2: I have taken: Prozac
column3: Paxil (yikes!)
column4: Celexa
column5: Lexapro
column6: Zoloft
column7: Effexor XR
column8: Serzone
column9: Trazodone
column10: Elavil
column11: and Pamelor.  In most cases
column12: either the side effects were intolerable or there was something ""missing."" When I began treatment with Cymbalta
column13: something clicked - and it felt wonderful.  Over the past couple of years
column14: I've been on/off it due to insurance b.s.  A little over two months ago
column15: I resumed taking Cymbalta 60mg/day.  My depression began to lift within two-three weeks
column16: then after a month
column17: my fibromyalgia symptoms decreased and my chronic back pain is GONE.

column1: The only side effects I've noticed are: very mild decrease in libido (hence only 4/5 stars on ease of use)
column2: a bit of sweating
column3: and occasionally a tad of urinary hesitation.  I'm guessing that Cymbalta has just the right balance of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition. (unlike most other SNRIs)

column1: Though it can be a bit pricey depending on your insurance
column2: I believe it is well worth it. Honestly
column3: I would recommend this medication to anyone- especially to those who have not responded to SSRIs and also those who suffer from the double-whammy of depression and a chronic pain syndrome.

column1: Best of luck!"

2101$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/7/2010 1:12:19 AM$Reviewer: Wloosue, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $1$1$4$It was a nightmare!  I lost my short-term memory, had severely stiff muscles and cramping, increased depression, intolerable insomnia, sugar cravings like you wouldn't believe (with related weight gain), joint pain, heart palpitations, tinnitus, hypertension, no libido, no motivation to do anything.  They don't give you enough information on side effects.  I didn't know I was having side effects until I found this web site.  I spent a month weaning myself off and felt dramatically better - like I have my life back. I actually started sleeping a little.  After  a month I threw the rest of my pills away and have been having some withdrawal.  It takes a while to get this poison out of your system, I guess.  The joint pain and muscle cramping are worse.  I feel a lot of intense, irrational anger, still have heart palpitations, tinnitus and hypertension.  At least I can sleep.  I made the decision to get off this stuff without consulting my dr. My experience with drs. is that they want to increase the dosage or add another pill to combat side effects rather than support a patient becoming drug free.  If depression becomes a problem in the future, I'll try a more natural approach to treating  it.  Right now, despite the withdrawal symptoms, I feel pretty terrific - better than I have felt in years.

The side effects are mild, initially(first three days) the side effects were horrible..drowiness, nausea, dissiness, but after that only minor ones...I seem to have either really weird dreams or really vivid ones(no sleepwalking though). Other side effects were tollerabe for me and the sexual side effect was positive for me. But overall the med was a fail for me. Initially it seemed like a God sent
column2: but over time it no longer worked and my doctor could not increase the dosage because of the effect that this med had on my blood pressure. Normaly I have perfect BP
column3: but Cymbalta pushed it to 160 over 110
column4: even on the lowest dosage (30 mg).

column1: I finally decided to get off of it and it has been 3 nights that I do not get any sleep! I feel extremely dizzy and nauseated all day long. I have done some research on this drug's withdrawal symptoms and it seems to be a consensus that it is like living hell.
If you are looking for an anti depressant - please do NOT take this. It is not worth it."

column1: 2143$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$7/15/2010 12:19:14 AM$Reviewer: Julia
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$1$4$I was on Cymbalta for almost 5 years on doses of 30 mg
column3: 60 mg
column4: and 120 mg. At fist
column5: I thought this was a wonderful medicine. But over time
column6: there was such a subtle change in my health. I gained weight and had more body aches
column7: less energy
column8: and muscle tension/aches. As my Doctor increased the dose
column9: the side effects increased but my Doctor was sure my symptoms had nothing to do with Cymbalta. With the increased weight gain came high blood pressure (I am 47). And not long ago
column10: I just was convinced that while the depression seemed under control
column11: I felt like I was dying in every other way. Then I just could no longer financially afford this very expensive medicine
column12: so I went off it. I stepped down the dose very carefully
column13: but the withdrawal symptoms left me feeling horrible. Each morning I had tremendous aches in my feet & hands
column14: then pinches of sharp pain all over & my peripheral vision seemed affected. It felt like my brain was having spasms.  I also had some headaches behind my eyes along with the other withdrawal symptoms. So I just stopped taking it all together. After a few months
column15: I haven't felt this good in YEARS!  I am so glad this toxic drug is out of my system.  I don't feel the physical pain of depression
column16: I have more energy & have begun to lose the weight! I am no longer running to my Doctor with so many complaints I felt I was dying! I would NOT recommend this drug to my worst enemy. Unless you want to slowly and subtly feel like you're dying in the process of handling depression
column17: this drug is horrible. And who wants to gain weight?? Talk about depressing!!!  The withdrawal from Cymbalta is scary
column18: I can't imagine what it was really doing to my brain.

column1: 2150$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$7/12/2010 12:38:54 AM$Reviewer: Bonnie
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$4$I started on this med after several months of being off antidepressants. I did a lot of research on it and decided it was worth a try. It took 5 or 6 weeks before I started feeling like myself again
column3: but I'm so glad I picked this drug! Here's my story: after 6 or 7 years on Celexa (which I had a good experience with) something went wrong. I still don't know what it was exactly
column4: but all of a sudden I was exhausted and had zero energy all the time. So I stopped the Celexa and was determined to stay off antidepressants and treat my depression naturally. Things were O.K. for a few months
column5: but eventually my anxiety/panic attacks/depression/suicidal thoughts got so bad I could not sleep
column6: eat
column7: or enjoy anything and I felt ill-at-ease every waking moment. I cried easily and got angry and hostile over the smallest things. It didn't help that I was just out of school
column8: unemployed
column9: and living in a city with 15% unemployment. The only response I got from sending out dozens of resumes/applications was a from a grocery store...which I worked at unhappily for 5 months (the average time of employment for me). On a side note
column10: I am certain I have Borderline Personality Disorder
column11: though I have not been officially diagnosed. Anyway
column12: if I hadn't gone on this drug when I did
column13: I'm not sure what would've happened to me. I'm sure I scared my husband of less than two years with all my drama. For me
column14: this drug was not effective right away; I spent the first couple of weeks on the couch unable to move unless I had to go to work
column15: bed
column16: or the bathroom. Now
column17: three months later I am fully functional again. The only problems I face now are 1) this drug is VERY expensive and 2) I am trying to get pregnant and both my psych dr. and OB/GYN tell me I need to stop taking it before the 3rd trimester if I do get pregnant. I'm not sure what to do yet because I don't want to go through another horrible depressive state again. For now
column18: things are good so I will count that as a blessing.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $1$1$3$In my experience this is the worse medication I have ever used and I have no idea why my psychiatrist prescribed it. In the beginning I was taking Prozac and Welbutrine and doing pretty well feeling ok. I told him I wanted to quit all mental type medications and then eventually get off all medications he agreed and suggest I start with weaning off prozac and welbutrine so I did. I felt some depression return so he prescribed Cymbalta. My 2 mistakes; First not researching the drug before starting it and trusting a doctor I did not know very well. Now since I am weaning off Cymbalta I am cursed to suffer 90% of all the bad side effects and there was never any benefit for me to take this drug and when I complained to my psychiatrist about it he just doubled the doseage. When my primary care Doctor found out he said that it was a very bad idea to take more then 60mgs. a day I was doing 120 by doctors orders
column3: never again!

column1: 2222$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$6/3/2010 3:52:41 PM$Reviewer: simplelife
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$2$1$I have been on Cymbalta for 5 yrs.  It will help with depression somewhat (as well as any other antidep) BUT the side effects far outweigh benefits.  The only reason I have taken so long is that it's extremely difficult to stop....Some other users ask if fast heartbeat
column3: anxious
column4: is normal with this med...that is actually a withdrawl symptom specific to Cymbalta. Problem is that it is so short acting that if you forget the dose or take it much later than the day before
column5: these syptoms will start immediately.  So users think its a side effect. There are many bad effects when first taking....but when they go away
column6: and your body becomes tolerant then med also slowly stops working....so after the first year you are really just taking med for no reason. Never heard anyone say it actually helps pain...I am transitioning to another med...not easy
column7: but did realise that syptoms I had for so long are now going away
column8: like sleepiness
column9: uncaring
column10: energy loss...and sex is now amazing...so MY advise is...only start this med if: the cost and doctor visits to get right dosage are not an issue
column11: you are militant about taking meds on time
column12: you are not in a relationship or care about sexual side effects
column13: you don't require much energy or concentration throughout the day
column14: and will be able to handle the pain if you ever have to stop taking med.

column1: 2275$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$4/29/2010 9:44:44 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$1$"This drug helped me feel happier and more stable for the first few months. Over time as my tolerance for the drug increased
column2: my symptoms increased
column3: and the dosage increased. I would feel better for a few months after an increased dosage. Eventually I was on the highest dosage but my symptoms were still getting worse. I felt like I was getting lower and more hopeless with each passing day. I ended up getting off the medication because of its lack of effectiveness and experienced intense withdrawal symptoms which included the following: migraines
column4: insomnia
column5: fever
column6: sweating
column7: nausea
column8: vomiting
column9: diarrhea
column10: anxiety attacks
column11: and more.  I had a migraine every day for over 3 months after stopping this medication.  After about 4 months without the medication I began feeling better. Now it's been 6 months off the medication and my depression
column12: sleepiness
column13: and mental and physical energy is largely better than it was when I was on the medication.  I'm back to my normal depressed state which isn't great
column14: but on the medication it was much worse. This medication truly made my depression worse and caused me to become suicidal.  I strongly suggest close monitoring of any young adult who takes this medication (as stated under Cymbalta's ""Warning"")
column15: and I also suggests tapering off the medication instead of quitting cold turkey.  Good luck everyone.  "

2301$Condition: Other$4/11/2010 2:47:59 PM$Reviewer: lily_of_the_valley
column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $2$1$4$"Took prescribed dose of Cymbalta for fibromyalgia.  Helped slightly.  However
column3: withdrawal has been extremely difficult; agony is the best word I can use to describe the symptoms.  Although gradually improving
column4: some symptoms remain 9 mos. after discontinuing this drug.  It is my opinion that it is of paramount importance to work with a physician prior to withdrawing from Cymbalta and do it very
column5: very slowly.  I weaned off of Cymbalta for the recommended 6 - 8 weeks
column6: but if I had it to do over again
column7: I would withdraw extremely slowly over the period of at least a year. I found many articles online in my in-depth research of Cymbalta; some refer to extremely slow withdrawal from the drug
column8: and a year or longer is recommended.  I wish I had found those particular articles before I started weaning off of Cymbalta.  Most of all
column9: I wish I had never taken it.

column1: I don't believe everyone has this same experience
column2: but my own research and my treatment by Dr.'s with extensive experience treating patients withdrawing from Cymbalta (rheumatologist
column3: ER physicians
column4: internist
column5: psychologist
column6: etc.) indicate a great many people do have very serious withdrawal from it. This is not the type of withdrawal people experience from an addictive substance
column7: but a possible and devastating disturbance of brain neurotransmitters.  Sickest I've ever been and still struggling.

column1: Please be careful and research side effects experienced by real people
column2: not just general information pertaining to Cymbalta
column3: before deciding to take it.  While Cymbalta helped the fibro somewhat
column4: the withdrawal was much
column5: much worse than the fibro pain
column6: and that's saying something.

column1: 2319$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$3/29/2010 3:01:31 PM$Reviewer: dlp61963
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$4$"I have been treated for PTSD
column3: anxiety and major depression for a lot of years. Cymbalta was prescribed to relieve anxiety. What I found was an immediate relief from irritability that I hadn't been aware I was experiencing. Relief from the irritability is what I like most about Cymbalta. I find that the discontinuation symptoms are comparable to Effexor XR except it takes much less time to experience them. From experience I have learned that it is important to be compliant about taking the medication as prescribed. Missing 1 day can bring on the brain ""zaps"" and a general unwell feeling. I also experience unsettling dreams if I miss doses. I take 60 mg a day. That seems to be a good therapeutic dose for me. The downfall is the ravenous appetite that others have experienced as well as feelings of weakness Eating does not relieve the hunger or the weakness
column4: but seems like the only logical thing to do to relieve the symptoms. As a result I have gained 5 pounds in a short time and if I continue on this track I will continue to gain weight. This is my biggest concern since I am normally fit
column5: thin and strong and currently feel exactly the opposite of that. It's a trade off feeling mentally good
column6: but physically not so much. Not sure what to do about it. All SSRIs and SNRIs cause those symptoms for me."

2331$Condition: Neuropathic Pain$3/23/2010 12:25:38 AM$Reviewer: kristalsky, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$120mg bid-was prescribe this med for neuropathy,very effective!helped my pain an improved my mood.side effects-hair loss;weight gain;brain zaps--severe pain & mood swings with missed dose but overall well worth taking! recommend
2332$Condition: Neuropathic Pain$3/22/2010 1:13:32 AM$Reviewer: Jancy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $1$1$4$I started taking Cymbalta for chronic pain. I'm not a depressive person, although I'd been under a lot of stress so I hoped it'd kill 2 birds with one stone, so to speak. Well... first morning after starting it, my eyes were so wide it felt like they were bugging out of their sockets! Weird, but it went away a week or so later. Next 5 months were uneventful. Didn't help pain at ALL. Not a bit. Doc increased the dose. Muscle tremors and jerks were happening every night when I'd start to relax. Huge, deep muscle twitches that would jerk me into a jack-knife position in bed. Very scary and weird. Next few months were again rather uneventful. I wanted to stop taking it because the only reason I started was pain control but my doc wanted me to stay on it for a year (why? don't know). At the one year marker, I let the Rx expire. And that's when the REAL fun began. I started getting muscle zaps; my whole body felt like I was being hit everywhere with a cattle prod. Loud noises, startle reflexes, stairs, rapid movement, turning my head...all these caused a zap feeling in my head that reverberated down my spine, into my arms and legs... It was awful. The depression that came down on top of that was horrific. It started the day before Christmas and continued until the first of February, which was the last day I noticed the zaps. It's now March 22 and I'm still feeling drained and a little depressed. There should be a BIG warning label about these types of side effects from going off it! I had Guillian Barre' Syndrome 22 years ago and wonder if having had an auto-immune disease in the past could have messed with the drug's interaction with me. Nevertheless, I could never recommend this drug to anyone...not even an enemy if I had one. 
2333$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$3/21/2010 6:37:41 PM$Reviewer: christenethomas, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years$4$4$5$
2334$Condition: Neuropathic Pain$3/20/2010 1:10:27 PM$Reviewer: Iamnotcrazy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $1$1$5$I took Cymbalta for depression and for nerve pain. Before I started taking this drug I Had a 3.4 grade point average. I was even inducted into Kappa Beta Delta Honor Society. About 4 months after starting Cymbalta
column5: my depression worsened
column6: my grade point average dropped to below 2.0
column7: and I stopped paying my bills. Last August I quit taking Cymbalta ""cold turkey"". The paranoia and brain zaps were the worst of the withdrawals
column8: there were others. Now I am trying to get not only my life
column9: but my husband's and child's as well back together. What I'm trying to get at
column10: is this drug did nothing for the nerve pain or my depression. So Please be very careful. If you notice yourself just not caring about anything talk to your doctor don't wait like I did. Before you know what's going on it might be to late. "

column11: caused my speech to slur
column12: and affected my balance and gait to the point of bumping into walls and tripping over my feet
column13: that the this doc shook her head and told me she would wean me off the Cymbalta and put me back on the Lyrica. column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$5$"I believe that the withdraw effects need to be clearly understood by patient before starting on this med.  I don't believe this is such a great treatment
column3: I was at 120mg quickly. I only saw good effects at each increase for about a month. I feel the public needs to be made aware of the total concept that comes when one chooses to starts this med.  I am not happy with the total results at 102mgs
column4: and I started at 30mgs. I have had other drugs added and stopped to make this drug work up to the potential it claims.  NO WHERE did I read of ""Brain Zaps"" as a possible reaction in all the literature I read previous to starting or wanting to STOP taking this drug. Only after searching the web did I discover what I was in for in STOPPING. FDA needs to get a much better handle on the true public info put out by the drug comnpanies which claim this is a ""Safe drug"".  Safe for the growth of their own pockets only.  I know of noone who has had great results or few effects especially when withdrawing from this med.  Just search the wed on cymbalta withdrawl and you'll find what I'm saying. 2481$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$1/10/2010 1:42:12 AM$Reviewer: celtickeep, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$I have used this medication since it came out, except for a brief 6 month break in which I used Prestiq and Lyrica.  Switching was a disaster!  Cymbalta is the best medication I have used.  It controls the pain of fibromyalgia very well and the depression is relieved to a manageable degree.  I take several other medications for bipolar, seroquel and topamax, and dexadrine so I can stay awake and alert during the day, and buspar for nighttime teeth grinding.  It's a lot of meds, but I'm surviving.  I live in the Pacific Northwest right now and the constant rain and dreary weather do not help, but we are moving and hopefully, the depression will improve with more sunshine.  I highly suggest Cymbalta.  I know different meds work for different people, but this one is worth a try.  I've used almost everyone out there and this is one of the best by far.  I've been medicated for since I was 12 and that's been 25 years now.  No novice here!  =)  Good luck with relief for your pain and depression.  God bless!

2525$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$12/27/2009 11:01:21 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$Cymbalta has been a Godsend for me!  I had been suffering from PTSD for almost 14 years and never knew what I was going through until I decided to do some research for myself which eventually led me to see a psychiatrist.  They say that it takes about 4 weeks for the medicine to get into your system before it starts to work, but I felt results within the first few days - certainly by the first week - of taking Cymbalta.  I felt normal again.  Maybe it worked so fast for me because I wasn't suffering from depression as a lot of other users were.  I started on 30mg and moved up to 60mg within a week.  The only side effects I had from the 60mg was extreme sleepiness (a lot of yawning) and I was unable to obtain an orgasm.  I went back down to 30mg, still some sleepiness although not as much, and I am able to achieve an orgasm.  Unfortunately the sensitivity I used to get from my nipples is no longer there.  They aren't numb or anything, I just don't get aroused anymore when they are touched (sorry if that's TMI, but I just want to let people know what may or may not happen to them while taking Cymbalta).  I'm going down to 20mg in a few days and I pray that the sensual feeling I used to get from my nipples being touched will return.  Oh yeah, I even skip a day sometimes and no terrible side effects.
2526$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$12/27/2009 10:16:19 PM$Reviewer: Lizzy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I have problems with depression mostly and some aniety. Cymbalta is a first choice of my doctor when the patient fits the criteria. I did and it works wonderful. I am able to stay at 60mg once a day. At one point after a death in my family my doctor uped my dosage to 90mg once daily. The side affect I expierenced with the 90mg is excessive 'sweating' not pleasent. she reduced my dosage back to 60mg and all is well. No side affects and I feel great mentally. I have been on Cymbalta oral for about 5 years.

2578$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$12/4/2009 5:46:24 AM$Reviewer: Cymbalta User, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$3$5$I have been taking this drug for several years.  I started out at just 30mg but now am all the way at 120mg.  If I am late taking this drug by 2 hours the horrible side effects begin.  If I miss it entirely I know it will be 24-48 hours before I feel okay again.  Some have asked what Brain Zaps are..... I describe them as kind of like an electric shock/dizziness and blankness all at once.  I have insomnia now as well and have gained 25 pounds.  I am very fearful of coming off of them so that my husband and I can have another child.  It has completely taken away my anxiety and the severe bouts with depression and suicidal ideations.  I still, however have never regained any intrest in doing anything.  I haven't tried therapy and have put all my hopes into medication, which is lazy, I know.  I don't believe I would recommend this medication to anyone unless you'd tried several others first.

2581$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$12/3/2009 7:44:20 AM$Reviewer: syl, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$4$I've been on Cymbalta for several years. I went off it about 8 months ago and now am back on due to current situation. I simply function better with meds. I want to tell everyone that Cymbalta is no worse going through withdrawl than other meds. It's scary if you don't understand it but it's a normal withdrawl process and something that lasts a few weeks. Symptoms are the same as when you start the med. It's just your body adjusting. If you're new to antidepressants, the whole thing can be a scary experience but a lot has to do with your perception and expectations. If you're apprehensive and looking for symptoms, you'll feel all of them. None of the withdrawl effects are that horrible compared to any other antideppressant. Paxil I heard is the worst. For me, the benefits far outweighed the negative side affects.

column1: 2598$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$11/26/2009 11:48:13 PM$Reviewer: Ryan from Texas
column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $3$2$4$I've lived most of my life with a severe panic disorder. When I was first diagnosed as a child I was put on paxil and it helped but later in life was switched to Cymbalta because of sexual side effects with paxil. Cymbalta worked great for my panic attacks
column3: it gave me energy I felt great
column4: I didn't have the constant overwhelming anxiety over my head and it was amazing... until the effects started wearing off. After about a year it felt like the Cymbalta was sucking energy from me instead of giving it to me
column5: I was tired physically and mentally
column6: I started getting bran zaps
column7: sometimes slurred speech
column8: confusion or brain fog
column9: and I could feel the anxiety slowly creeping back in the picture. So my doctor switched me over to Prozac however getting off of Cymbalta is no easy task! You experience horrible withdrawal symptoms such as: horrible physical pain and weakness
column10: brain fog
column11: uncontrollable muscle tremors
column12: extreme nausea
column13: feelings of being lost or out of place
column14: intense periods of depression and crying
column15: heart palpitations
column16: dizziness
column17: extreme anger
column18: migraines
column19: and the list goes on. To say the least
column20: it's no cake walk and you probably will slip and take one just for a break in the withdrawal symptoms but be strong and stay at it and the symptoms will slowly subside. I finally stopped having withdrawal symptoms about 2 months after stopping Cymbalta. I implore anyone researching Cymbalta to try Prozac first; I've been on it for about a year and a half now and couldn't be happier. I hope this helps! Always remember you're not alone in this and stay positive. Never give up hope
column21: life is beautiful behind the veil of depression and anxiety. Tomorrow the sun will rise and bring with it a new day with many new possibilities :) God bless!

column1: 2599$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$11/26/2009 12:05:59 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$I first started off with lexapro but it gave me sexual side effects. Then i tried Wellbutrin but i just felt weird. Finally i tried cymbalta and i can say i had no side effects besides sleepiness for the first 2 days. My doctor started me off with 30 for about 6 weeks and then i started the 60. I can really say i am such a different person now then i was six months ago. All i can say is all antideprassants will react differently to different people and its just a matter of finding one that works for you!

column1: 2633$Condition: Other$11/11/2009 9:46:51 AM$Reviewer: Nay
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month$3$3$5$"Just started taking Cymbalta after it came highly reccommended from my Psychiatrist. Have tried Zoloft
column3: Lexapro
column4: Effexor
column5: Pristiq
column6: Seroquel(for sleep)
column7: Trileptal. Gave all of these at least a month but wasn't sleeping well. Could have lost sleep
column8: tried to get through the side effects period but sleep is more important if you have sleep issues for 10 years. So far Cymbalta seems okay after a few days
column9: I take Melatonin 1.5 to 3 mg for sleep and a Cortisol herb for keeping it low during the night so not to awaken at 3:00am. I have a small Pituitary tumor that is causing the problems
column10: high cortisol
column11: anxiety
column12: ect. So I know the reason and until it shrinks I must treat the symptoms with medications
column13: Cymbalta and 100 mg Lamictal. I tried to have an operation to remove it but they couldn't reach it as I bleed too much. So back to plan B
column14: shrink it with alternative ways. Omegas or medicinal mushrooms.

column1: I don't know if anyone out there has gotten to the root cause of your depressions or anxiety as I have. It may be more than a chemical imbalance. Food allergies
column2: gluten intolerance
column3: low thyroid
column4: pituitary or adrenal tumors
column5: although Rare
column6: ect. Your primary docs can run blood tests to check for food allergies and hormone levels like thryoid
column7: adrenals ect. There are saliva tests you can google on line to check all sorts of things in the body
column8: these test are very accurate and you can bring them to your doctors. The docs are so quick to give out meds. but don't run these tests unless you ask them. We are the advocates for our own bodies and must do the leg work to feel 100% better. The meds. help but sometimes are not he only answer as they may not address the root cause. Anyway
column9: I have been researching for 10 years and finally think I am on the road to restoring my health. Good luck to you all. Hope this helped and don't give up
column10: the answer can be simple."

column4: and the pain increased and spread toother parts of his body. Now that we are trying to wan him off
column5: the withdrawals are horrible! The suffering this man has had to endure is inhumane at the least. I don't believe the doctors were properly educated on this terrible drug so in turn patients aren't able to make a clear educated decision as to take this medication to begin with. I have placed a complaint with th FDA as well as with Eli Lilly. I have also placed a complaint with his doctor. I am so angry and to know that the weaning process will takes months is just unacceptable to me. Get online and type in Cymbalta withdrawal and Cymbalta side efffects and see the other hundreds of people who are suffering with little to no help from the medical field. Also
column6: you will see the desperate attempts of some who are trying to get off this drug. There WILL be a death as a result of some of these tactics and I forsee a class action law suit in he future for Eli Lilly and any of the medical professionals who refuse to hear the cries of so many desperate people.

2667$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$10/25/2009 11:37:57 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $1$1$4$"I have tried several antidepressants over the years (Paxil CR
column2: Lexapro
column3: Wellbutrin) for my depression and anxiety
column4: but I have not been satisfied with any of them for various reasons.  I thought I had found a great one when I started taking Cymbalta back in February.  Sure
column5: the adjustment period wasn't great (but I did lose some weight from the loss of appetite!)
column6: but my mood seemed better and all that.  I increased from 30 mg up to 60 about 3 mos later.  Then starting in about June
column7: I noticed my terrible insomnia and lack of energy.  I have gained weight
column8: causing me great distress
column9: because I have no energy to work out and no food is completely satisfying so I eat more.  It finally occurred to me last week that it could be the Cymbalta so I stopped taking it cold turkey.  Immediately
column10: my sleep improved
column11: I have happier dreams
column12: and I feel more energetic during the day.  My only problem now is suffering through this wretched withdrawal.  I feel hungry
column13: but I can't keep any food down
column14: and the vertigo and ""brain zaps"" are awful.  I have never had withdrawal from any Rx like this.  I hate feeling sick
column15: but I know I need to get through it to be happy again.  I am in a stable emotional situation now
column16: so I feel like I can live without any medication once I get my energy back.  I only wish I had made the connection earlier."

column1: 2683$Condition: Disorder characterized by Stiff
column2: Tender & Painful Muscles$10/17/2009 2:17:50 AM$Reviewer: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $1$1$5$"I switched from Prozac to Cymbalta.  I've tried Cymbalta 3 times and has already made my depression noticeably worse.  I've given it a good amount of time.

column1: I started reading the advertisements about Fibromyalgia and neuropathic pain but was somewhat skeptical.  My skepticism turned out right in my case.  My pain levels were MUCH
column2: MUCH worse.  I really wish Cymbalta wasn't a sponsor and all over the place on this site advertising about Fibromyalgia pain.  It must work for some people
column3: but plain 'ol Prozac worked better in my specific case.

column1: I also take a ton of other meds for the pain and symptoms of FMS
column2: including Norco
column3: Zanaflex
column4: Neurontin (Lyrica)
column5: Ibuprofen and I've forgotten a few.

column1: One warning
column2: don't take tramadol (Ultram) with SSRI's as you can get a very serious condition called ""Serotonin Syndrome"" which I had.  I didn't see any warnings above.  Taking ""regular narcotics"" unlike tramadol
column3: like Vicodin and Oxycontin is OK with SSRI's according to my pharmacist.

column1: I just don't like seeing them advertising and be approved for fibromyalgia pain.  I've had it 17 years and have tried (and researched) everything.  I was taking Neurontin many years before it (Lyrica-similar) was approved for FMS.
But I must say
column2: I am happy that in that 17 years
column3: doctors are finally starting to understand the devastation of Fibromyalgia a little better.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: if you asked the average person if they've ever heard of it
column3: they'd say no unless they knew someone with it.  And even if they did
column4: they still wouldn't quite understand the devastation.

column1: I do like the multiple articles addressing FMS on this site now
column2: but I see the darned Cymbalta ads on top of every one.  And the placebos are catching up to the drugs now.

column1: I think (I may be wrong) when Prozac was approved
column2: it had was 47 percent effective as compared to 43 percent on the the placebo.  And that was enough for them to make billions.

column1: Pedro"

column1: 2695$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$10/14/2009 1:50:11 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$Be Careful! Finding the right antidepressant is tricky. My doctor recommended cymbalta for me when lexapro wasnt cutting it

2752$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$9/19/2009 11:57:06 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$1$My doc put me on Cymbalta for severe anxiety disorders & OCD. Started out with 30mgs for a month then went to 60mgs for a month. At first everything was okay, just a lot of yawning and sleeping. Then I began to have night sweats, started getting shaking, & headaches. After about a month of 60mgs I had completely cut myself off from having a social life & began having horrible thoughts of not wanting to live. Also began having uncontrolled crying fits and screaming at my boyfriend for no reason at all. No memory of these occurances. Began walking around in my sleep and moving things around my house. Decided to take myself off the med by going back down to 30mgs for 2 weeks & then stopping completely. Was the worst withdrawal symptoms of my life. Last night I had a mirgrane for 6 hours, threw up, and cried for at least 45 minutes straight for no reason. Woke up with the shakes. I do not suggest this drug for any one!!!!

2758$Condition: Disorder characterized by Stiff
column2: Tender & Painful Muscles$9/17/2009 8:10:57 PM$Reviewer: TracyInIdaho
column3: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$Give it a chance!  For the first month
column4: I hated this medicine.  It caused headaches
column5: dizziness and constipation.  It was helping with none of my pain
column6: and I wanted to go off of it for fear of all of the bad side effects I had heard about.  Now...I have been on this medicine for 9 months and it has saved my life.  I can now sleep at night
column7: I no longer am stiff in all my joints.  I have spinal stenosis caused by degenerative disc and facet disease.  I spent years taking different pain killers and receiving shots.  Nothing worked and Cymbalta was my last hope before surgery.  Lyrica made me feel dead
column8: so I gave Cymbalta a try.  i am so glad I didn't give up.  My life is so much better now.  My body hasn't felt this good since I was a teenager.  I have also lost 15 lbs since it does drop your appetite somewhat.  I have done several reviews on this drug over the past 9 months.  Each month that goes by I am happier and happier with my progress.  I have almost forgotten the days that i couldn't get out of bed in the morning or bend over to pick up my son.  I am sure it doesn't work for everyone
column9: as all drugs react differently for different people
column10: but give it more than a month before you decide.  As for going off of it
column11: I am afraid there will probably be withdrawl type symptoms.  Being a time-released capsule
column12: my body definitely knows when 24 hours has passed and become quite dependent on this drug.  I will take that chance though for the way I feel every day now.  I am raising 4 children and this is the best I have ever felt after giving birth to any of them.  Cymbalta has saved me from surgery and makes my life so much easier and pain free.

column3: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$5$"1992 diagnosed with FM & CF. Have tried all types of meds. column1: Now with a little over 2 years
column2: my combo plan of Cymbalta & Wellbutrin has quit on me.

column1: Just started Savella 3 days ago and coming off of Cymbalta.
I have been SO dizzy I'm knocking into things. That is ""without"" Vicodin for the inquiring minds that would like to know. I took the pain med later but needed to know that wasn't the problem.
So if the Cymbalta isn't fulling changing things for you with FM&CF ask your doc about adding the Wellbutrin. It gave me energy that I hadn't had in YEARS!

column1: 2830$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/19/2009 1:24:15 AM$Reviewer: Silkenrage
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$"Cymbalta is a miracle to me! Ive been on every antidepressant in existance over the past 10 years. Nothing ever worked and I just walked around like a zombie with no care for my life at all.

column1: Cymbalta has woken me up and I can go outside and smile and drive and am so happy. My 2 children and the rest of my family are amazed.
I can't make it without Cymbalta and now...

I tried to refill my Cymbalta on 8/17/09 because I only had enough to get me through 8/18/09. Walmart and Sams insurance no longer pays for Cymbalta and I had all of one day notice before I ran out of medication. It will cost over $450 to refill. I don't even have $100 in my bank account. I am sooooooooo upset and terrified. Everywhere I call gets no help. I am now out of pills and wont be able to take my morning dose.
I called my doctor 3x on Monday
column2: 8/17/09 and the receptionist called her and I was told that they had no samples.

column1: My next question is ""ok
column2: and?"" I really don't understand. I have read post after post from people going through hell as they get off cymbalta and they had pills to take lower dosages as the days went by. I have NOTHING. God gave me my life back and I am so hurt that I am losing it. I don't want to be the way I used to be. I never left my bedroom and I didnt even check the mail. As of the last month
column3: I am rarely in my room except to sleep and I spend lots of time with my family. My kids deserve to have a real mom for once and they will be hurt by this just as much as it is going to hurt me.

column1: I don't know what to do :(

column1: 2832$Condition: Other$8/17/2009 4:32:13 PM$Reviewer: Amy In SC
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$3$5$"Let me start off by saying that everyone will have a different reaction to these kinds of medications. I've had anxiety & depression since my early 20's
column3: & taken every med on the market - Prozac
column4: Celexa
column5: Zoloft
column6: Effexor
column7: Wellbutrin
column8: you name it. When Cymbalta came out
column9: of course I asked my doctor if I could try it. It helped a lot...I didn't have that ""empty
column10: out of it"" feeling I got from the Zoloft & Effexor. I was happy and it helped with the depression
column11: but did NOT do a whole lot for my anxiety (which I realize there are other meds for that
column12: Cymbalta is mainly for the depression). I was pleasant & could think clearly and function normally
column13: for the most part.

column1: However...I gained a LOT of weight while I was on Cymbalta. I didn't know this was a side-effect when I started taking it
column2: and the Cymbalta really ""packed it on"" (to the tune of about 25 lbs in 4 months). I never gained that kind of weight on the other depression meds that I've taken in the past.

column1: On a scale of 1-10
column2: I'd give Cymbalta a 7 in regards to it's effect on the depression. In the end
column3: I couldn't deal with the weight gain (I've never been an overweight person)
column4: so I asked my doctor to put me back on the Wellbutrin
column5: which has a similar effect as Cymbalta (in my experience) but without the weight gain. This is just my experience with the drug. Cymbalta isn't horrible at all
column6: actually it helps a great deal...but it made me gain a lot of weight
column7: so I switched back to something that I knew worked just as well & didn't cause the weight gain. Give it a try
column8: everyone's experiences & reactions to these kinds of medications are different. Unfortunately Cymbalta just wasn't for me.

column1:
2833$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/17/2009 11:46:39 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$3$5$You know when I started taking this medication when it first came out in 2004 I thought it was amazing. I thought I felt better and I thought I was dealing with life better. Now that I dumped all my pills down the toilet, because, I couldn't afford them and I was tired of being dependent on a pill, I feel so much better. On Cymbalta or any of the other depression pills I have been on I never really felt better. I thought I was better because the Doctors always told me, this will make you feel better. I have been on depression medication since I was 16 years old and I am now 28 (I couldn't remember what it was like to not be on a pill). Now that I am off my medication my suicidal thoughts have almost depleted. I don't feel so tired all the time and my IBS is going away. Not to say that depression medication does not help people, but, I can honestly say that I feel 10 times better being off of it than I did on it. I hope this helps someone.

column1: 2842$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/14/2009 1:32:41 PM$Reviewer: marcie
column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$5$"I saw the ads for this medication and thought it sounded like the best thing since sliced bread.   I looked it up online and decided that it would be safe enough
column3: hassle-free enough
column4: and so I asked my doctor for a prescription.

column1: After about two months
column2: I noticed that I was getting small lumps under my skin -- about a dozen of them -- that seemed to be growing kind of fast.  I didn't associate it with Cymbalta
column3: they didn't actually hurt
column4: and I had a follow-up appointment with my doctor in about a month
column5: so I didn't do anything.

column1: Then
column2: we discovered a lump in my breast
column3: on my chest wall and immovable.  Needless to say
column4: I went to the doctor right away.   He said he didn't know the cause of any of the bumps
column5: but got me a referral to a surgeon right away for the one in my breast.

column1: I had the lump removed -- went through the risk of surgery with general anesthesia.  The cytology showed that the lump was not cancer
column2: but a lipoma -- a cyst of fat.

column1: I looked up every one of my meds online
column2: read every single possible problem with them.  Lo and behold one of the things Cymbalta could do was cause lipomas.  I  took myself off of it
column3: tapered off.

column1: That was all about 4 years ago.   I still have the other lumps
column2: though they might be marginally smaller. "

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$3$5$I switched from Effexor to Cymbalta because I still didn't feel as positive as I wanted to. Initially
column3: it worked pretty well. However
column4: over time it was just like the Effexor. I had gone off Effexor in the past and suffered only minor feelings of restlessness
column5: anxiety
column6: sweating and some nausea. Not so with Cymbalta. I ran out
column7: and within 4 days of having weaned myself off (I went from 120 mg to 60 to 0)
column8: began feeling such despair and hopelessness. I was sweating profusely
column9: felt disoriented - like I didn't belong anywhere
column10: crying
column11: my entire body began to spasm. I vomited (severe
column12: wretched) for 3 days. I couldn't even keep water down. I became dehydrated. I was shaking and shivering so hard my teeth rattled. I now have an idea what a junkie must feel like when detoxing from Heroin. I felt like a complete zombie. I have never felt so horrible in all my life. Whatever you do
column13: DO NOT stop using Cymbalta unless you're in the hospital or have a health care professional in your home. I went back on Cymbalta as soon as I found someone to go to the pharmacy. There was no alternative. It would appear that I'll be taking this medication for the rest of my life. I can't go through the withdrawals agan. No way. I lost 2 weeks of my life. I don't know what it's the pharmacological make-up of this drug is. How can it cause such horrific symptoms when your body is deproved of it when it really doesn't work all that great?

2876$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$8/4/2009 2:00:29 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$5$Side effects started right away, primarily teeth clenching (very painful), but also anxiety, sleep diturbances, rashes, fever, and then the diarrhea started and got worse and worse and worse, 40 days of it, the last two weeks in a diaper, mostly bile since I couldn't eat. Swelling in my colon so bad I couldn't sit up. Was in bed exhausted. thought I was going to die from dehydration or liver problems. Quit cold turkey and got better right away but quitting made me very dizzy and very cold for several days. Worse medicine I've ever been on. Started at 30mg, then went to 60mg. column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$2$4$"Cymbalta worked great for my anxiety and back pain. The downside is from the moment I started taking it my appetite went to zero
column3: all food cravings disapped
column4: sex drive decreased; and received orgasm disfuction in return. Motivation to do anything physical nearly disappeared. Before Cymbalta I was a regular gym rat going to the gym a minimum of four times a week. With a decrease in appetite and eating very little
column5: I am still trying to figure out why I gained 10 pounds.

column1: My Dr wanted me to go from 60 mg to 90 mg because its effectiveness was wearing off. Two days after going to 90 mg I started having horrible stomach pain. Awoke every morning with nausea
column2: could only eat very little throughout the day. I have taken myself from 90 mg to 60 mg to 30 mg to 30 mg every other day. I have now completely stopped. My head is swimming and my stomach is still having some problems; but getting better. I can eat some what regularly.

column1: It helped with my back and my anxiety; but the side effects were NOT worth it. I would warn anyone that is going to take Cymbalta to do your research and read up on the side effects. If you have them
column2: stop taking it and talk to your doctor. I pointed the side effects out to my Dr; but he wanted me to stay on it for my back. I am now on LorTab 7.5 twice a day. I have been on narcotics before for my back and that was much easier to withdrawal from than Cymbalta."

column1: 2992$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$6/29/2009 12:41:27 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$1$"I don't even know where to start! I've been on a variety of different anti-depressants over the years
column2: but Cymbalta has been
column3: by far
column4: the least effective. Not only did I start having very disturbing dreams and restless sleep
column5: but I didn't see any improvement in my mood. I felt more hopeless than ever before.

column1: One thing that I want anyone considering Cymbalta to know is that the Discontinuation Syndrome for this drug is horrendous. I'm slowly tapering off of Cymbalta right now and it's been the worst experience of my life. I feel like my body is shutting down. I've been incredibly nauseous
column2: irritable
column3: and generally out of sorts. I feel foggy and confused and I don't know what to do about it! I wish my psychiatrist would have told me about this when I started taking Cymbalta.

column1: Really weigh the pros and cons when considering Cymbalta as an option. Even if this drug does work for your depression (or other needs)
column2: if you don't plan on being on it forever
column3: think about the discontinuation side effects because
column4: personally and without being too dramatic
column5: they are destroying my ability to function right now."

I was never this way and the worst side affects in the last 6 months is the itching in my legs and head and the horrible sweating.  It's really bad. I feel like I have bugs crawling in my head and in my legs.  I read about all the drug interactions too.  I should have read them sooner.  You have to really be careful not to take anything that can make your heart stop working.  I tried to wean myself from this medication to no avail.  I had real bad anxiety and crying spells and horrible dreams too.  Is there anything out there that works better.

column1: 3113$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$5/18/2009 8:50:34 PM$Reviewer: lucky13
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$3$"PLEASE READ THIS IF YOU'RE COMING OFF CYMBALTA!  There are some real horror stories on here.  I had a great Dr. managing my meds...I was very concerned about withdrawal side effects
column3: so we took over 3 months to get me off it after I was ""done"" (I was on it for 1 yr after it had started working to make sure I did not relapse after coming off).  Don't rush!  If you rush
column4: you get bad side effects.  I started at 60mg and went down 10mg every 2 weeks.  Near the end she had me open the 20mg capsule
column5: dump about half the contents out and reclose capsule and take it.  Then I took about 1/4 capsule.  Then I went to 1/4 capsule every other day.  I started to get bad vertigo at one point
column6: so she had me step back to last dosage and start to decrease again once no side effects were there.  She also warned me that during withdrawal you can get what appears to be depression symptoms back (e.g. moodiness
column7: lack of patience
column8: crying for no reason
column9: etc).  I'm glad she did - otherwise I might have thought I needed to go back on it vs. it being a temporary thing while getting off the meds.  It took over 3 months
column10: but the process was a smooth one and I feel terrific.  Also - remember that people tend to read and write reviews on meds when they're experience isn't that great.  Most of these reviews sound terrible - but they are not a balanced view of what the med can do for you.  Most of the people with no problems won't have a reason to take the time to come on here.  Be patient with it!  If you have lots of withdrawal side effects
column11: talk to your Doc and slow the process down.  There's no reason you have to feel terrible through it all.  Cymbalta gave me my life back.  I am a better wife
column12: mother and friend after being on it.  I would do it all over again if I had to."

column1: 3136$Condition: Other$5/9/2009 6:28:27 AM$Reviewer: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $3$1$5$My doctor started me on Cymbalta for fibromyaaglia after trying Lyrica and having bad side effects. I was on Cymbalta for a total of 3 weeks 2 weeks at 30mg and 1 week of 60 mg. I had ablood test done after the first 2 weeks and my liver readings were 4-5 times what is normal. So the doctor immediately took me off the Cymbalta and all other meds & vitamins to let the liver heal. Will have a blood test in 3 weeks to see if everything is back to normal. I would not have known about the liver damage if I hadn't had the blood test for my scheduled physical. So if you are on this medicine I would highly recommend getting blood checks for your liver.

column3: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $1$1$4$I was placed on Cymbalta for pain. For two years I taken this medication once a day every day. I began to have cramping in my feet. Then legs; then neck;stomach;chest. Sometimes the cramping were so servere I want someone to put me out of my pain! I began to have blood spots forming under my skin. I would talk to my doctors about this problem. No one listened to me. I taken all I could take.... I STOPPED THIS MEDICATION. Two weeks after stopping all the symptoms stopped. No more cramping
column4: no more blood spots under the skin. My doctor use to tell me to eat banans;drink water; but never did my doctors tell me that Cymbalta was causing this problem. Sometimes we need to sit back and take a hard look at our doctors. They are not always right and they do not always listen to us. I am a much happier person.....twisting-cramping and blood spots all came from this medication.

column1: 3159$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$4/29/2009 12:40:55 PM$Reviewer: Ahlmost
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$Overall this is a good drug for me. I have been taking it for 2 months and I saw an improvement right away and it just keeps getting better. The only major side effect for me is the insomnia I experience every night. I only seem to get 3-4 hours of sleep a night. My doctor warned me about this and gave me some samples of Lunesta that work really well.  I will be taking that from now on before bed. Do not take Cymbalta before bed! It puts you in a 1/2 sleep 1/2 wake state with awful nightmares! Take first thing in the morning to avoid the dreaded dreams. Also
column3: I do wake up damp from sweating but it isn't a real issue for me compared to what I was going through before. Hope this helps!!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I have had depression off and on for the last 25 years and have previously taken paxil for the depression with anxiety. column3: crying all of the time
column4: very anxious about not being able to return to my work as a RN. My doctor put me on 30mg of Cymbalta once a day. I took it for a month
column5: but really felt no effects until it was raised to 60mg once a day. It was like night and day for me. I felt so much better about myself and I wasn't crying all of the time. Instead of dwelling on what I couldn't do
column6: I concentrated on what I could. I went back to school online while I was still unable to work and got my BBA with a concentration in healthcare. I am now working at a new job as a RN in a new youth mental health facitlity and working at getting my MBA. The only side effects that really bother me is the excessive sweating night and day and the weight gain. I can deal with those side effects because my outlook on life is so much better.

I would suggest limiting caffeine intake though, especially if it is prescribed for anxiety.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$2$"just recently started-about 4 weeks ago for anxiety and irritability.  when i say irritability i mean the flipping out for no reason and getting even more mad because of it type of irritibility. i noticed effects after first week.  did help mood--not so irritable but caused hot flashes.  only my face would sweat and would be dripping even when sitting and relaxing.  started by taking in the morning but by noon was too tired to sleep and could not stop yawning.  tried taking it in afternoon but headaches before bed.  finally settled on right before bed.  that worked the best even though felt a little dizzy in early morning.  when refill time came up i had some trouble filling it and missed a few days.  i could tell immediately when it was no longer in my system.  the same irritability from before came back and i was so relieved when i finally did get my refill--after having missed three days.  i have not been on it long enough to be sure this is the thing for me
column3: but it has been working and i'm thankful for that.  i gladly put up with the before mentioned side effects oh and some side effects in the bedroom as well.  i've given up trying to orgasm because the road there is just too long and now most times giving up is all i can do. but
column4: at least i'm not the crazy
column5: angry monster i used to be. i can gladly live without a climax if it means being able to take care of my children like other ""normal"" mothers.  i hope that this is the one for me."
